summary: This document is a series of forwarded emails from Chris Dilorio, a self-described whistleblower, sent between April and July 2019. The emails allege widespread financial crimes, securities fraud, and money laundering involving numerous high-profile individuals and entities connected to Jeffrey Epstein, Apollo Global Management, the Kushner family, and the Trump administration. The author accuses the SEC and other agencies of corruption and cover-ups.

persons.name: Chris Dilorio
persons.context: Author of the emails, making extensive allegations of financial crimes, securities fraud, and corruption involving Epstein, Apollo, Kushner, and others. Identifies as a whistleblower.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Allegedly involved in money laundering shells and a Ponzi scheme. Connected to Leon Black and Apollo. His Financial Trust Company Inc. filed with the SEC in relation to Environmental Solutions Worldwide.

persons.name: Leon Black
persons.context: Portrayed as a central figure in alleged financial crimes, connected to Epstein, Kushner, and Russian interests. A former associate of Michael Milken.

persons.name: Jared Kushner
persons.role: Senior White House Advisor/Son-in-law of President Trump
persons.context: Allegedly connected to Apollo financing (666 Fifth Ave deal), and implicated in favorable SEC treatment for Apollo after meetings.

persons.name: Brian Colleran
persons.context: Hosted a Trump fundraiser. His companies settled False Claims Act allegations for $19.5 million.

persons.name: Stephen Calk
persons.context: Charged with corruptly soliciting a presidential administration position in exchange for loans.

persons.name: Phillip Frost
persons.context: Charged by the SEC in pump-and-dump stock schemes. Connected to alleged money laundering shells.

persons.name: Martin Schlaff
persons.context: Described as a 'Bag Man' involved in investments and alleged money laundering through Alpha Capital.

persons.name: Stephanie Avakian
persons.context: Mentioned in context of the SEC dropping an investigation into Apollo after Kushner meetings.

persons.name: Howard Heiss
persons.context: Attorney with a focus on securities matters; mentioned in the context of Apollo's legal representation.

persons.name: Stephen Feinberg
persons.context: Chosen by Trump to lead an intelligence advisory panel. Connected to Bawag/Refco and money laundering allegations.

persons.name: George Economou
persons.context: Also known as Georgios Ekonomou. Allegedly involved in money laundering shells like DryShips. Connected to Marc Bistricer and AQR.

persons.name: Andrew Ekonomou
persons.context: Medieval historian turned attorney who worked on Trump's legal team for the Russia investigation. Implied connection to George Economou.

persons.name: Marc Bistricer
persons.context: Toronto-based investor allegedly involved in the DryShips/Ekonomou shell company.

persons.name: Joshua Harris
persons.context: Apollo founding partner who met with Kushner at the White House and was considered for a job.

persons.name: Nathan Milikowsky
persons.context: Cousin of Benjamin Netanyahu, led 'Save GrafTech' investor group. Connected to GrafTech fraud allegations.

persons.name: Chad Readler
persons.context: Former Acting Assistant Attorney General who became a Circuit Judge. Mentioned as part of 'criminality' associated with the White House.

persons.name: Daniel Parker
persons.context: Executive, along with Brian Colleran, whose companies settled False Claims Act allegations.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: Named in the press release about charges against bank CEO Stephen Calk.

persons.name: Eliot Spitzer
persons.role: Former New York State Attorney General
persons.context: Announced indictments in a boiler room stock fraud scheme; later referenced as being 'taken down by a Russian hooker'.

persons.name: Robert Mueller
persons.context: Joined WilmerHale law firm after serving as FBI Director.

persons.name: Jamie Gorelick
persons.context: Washington litigator at WilmerHale, the firm that also employed Robert Mueller.

persons.name: Mark Yung
persons.context: Listed on the board of ESW Group (Environmental Solutions Worldwide).

connections.description: Alleged financial and business connections. Epstein's Financial Trust Company filed an SEC document related to an Apollo-connected company (Environmental Solutions Worldwide).
Apollo provided financing for Kushner's 666 Fifth Avenue property. Kushner met with Apollo's Joshua Harris at the White House.
Author alleges the SEC dropped an investigation into Apollo shortly after the firm loaned money to Kushner Companies.
Calk charged with corruptly soliciting a presidential administration position in exchange for approving loans.
Bistricer allegedly invested in Economou's DryShips, characterized as a money laundering shell.
Frost connected to alleged money laundering shells, with Alpha Capital Anstalt implicated as a vehicle.
Author claims Spitzer was 'taken down by a Russian hooker', implying a compromising connection.
Implied familial or name connection between Trump attorney Andrew Ekonomou and Greek shipper George Economou (Ekonomou).

events.title: Trump Fundraiser at Brian Colleran's Home
events.description: President Donald Trump held a private fundraiser at the Cleveland home of nursing home executive Brian Colleran.

events.title: NYT Article on Epstein's Finances
events.description: New York Times publishes article questioning Jeffrey Epstein's wealth, titled 'Jeffrey Epstein's 'Infinite Means' May Be a Mirage'.

events.title: SEC Approves AQR Shell
events.description: The SEC approved another 'massive fraud on the investing public'â€”an AQR/Greek shipping-related money laundering shell, per the author.

events.title: SEC Drops Apollo Investigation
events.description: The SEC dropped an investigation into Apollo Global Management a month after the firm gave Kushner Companies a $180 million loan.

events.title: $19.5 Million False Claims Act Settlement
events.description: Brian Colleran and Daniel Parker's companies (Foundations Health Solutions, Olympia Therapy, Tridia Hospice) paid $19.5 million to resolve allegations of submitting false claims for medically unnecessary services.

events.title: Apollo/Citigroup Loan to Kushner Companies
events.description: Apollo and Citigroup loaned hundreds of millions to Kushner Companies, and Kushner discussed a White House job for Apollo founder Josh Harris.

keyFacts: The author, Chris Dilorio, alleges a vast network of financial crimes connecting Jeffrey Epstein, Apollo Global Management (Leon Black, Joshua Harris), the Kushner family, and the Trump administration, centered on money laundering through public shell companies.

A core allegation is that the SEC corruptly dropped an investigation into Apollo Global Management in 2018, shortly after Apollo provided a major loan to Kushner Companies and after Jared Kushner met with Apollo's Joshua Harris.

The document references specific shell companies allegedly used for fraud and money laundering, including Environmental Solutions Worldwide (ESWW), DryShips, and entities connected to Alpha Capital Anstalt.

The author claims that 'abusive naked shorting' of publicly traded shells on the OTC markets is a primary method used to facilitate money laundering, and that regulators intentionally allow this to continue.

Multiple high-profile individuals are implicated in the alleged network, including Greek shipper George Economou, investors Marc Bistricer and Phillip Frost, and Trump attorney Andrew Ekonomou, suggesting an international dimension to the schemes.
